Authors: Pradipta I.A., Maulana Y., Sanjaya Jio I.M.
Title: Factors that affecting purchase decision on automotive workshop official store in e-commerce
Source title: Proceedings of 2020 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2020
Affiliations: BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, International Marketing Program, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, Tourism Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pradipta, I.A., BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, International Marketing Program, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Maulana, Y., Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, Tourism Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sanjaya Jio, I.M., BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, International Marketing Program, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This research is conducted to find out what factors that affecting purchase decision in automotive workshop official store in E-commerce, considering that social media users and vehicle owners will increase continuously. In its implementation, this research uses quantitative methods and uses path analysis as a method of analyzing data that has been collected, as many as 120 respondents by spreading online's questionnaires. The results of this research show that social media marketing has a significant influence on brand awareness. And brand awareness has a significant influence on purchase decision. Also, social media marketing has a positive and significant influence on purchase decisions through brand awareness. There is a significant effect between Social Media Marketing, brand awareness on purchase decision. © 2020 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Brand awareness; Purchase decision; Social media marketing
Index Keywords: Electronic commerce; Information management; Regression analysis; Social networking (online); Surveys; Brand awareness; Path analysis; Purchase decision; Quantitative method; Social media; Social media marketings; Sales

Title: Strategic planning for developing coffee as a tourist attraction in Rural Area (Case study: Campakamulya Village, Bandung, West Java, Indonesia)
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Syahchari, D.H., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Maulana, Y., Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This research aims to develop strategic planning for rural coffee tourism at Campakamulya Village. Puntang Coffee has successfully become one of the winners in the worldwide coffee competition based on the Specialty Coffee Association of America (SCAA). Campakamulya Village is one of the producers of Puntang Coffee. Coffee as a tourist attraction is one of the key element in rural tourism performance and also as a tool to develop tourism in the area. The PESTLE analysis is used to assess the external factors about rural coffee tourism situation in Campakamulya Village. It also helps to identify factors for developing strategic planning and give conclusions. This research contributes to the community regarding the planning of the rural tourism strategy with an emphasis on coffee as an attraction can contribute to the development of the rural area and integrated approaches to sustainable development. © Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Strategic planning; Sustainable development; Tourism; External factors; Indonesia; Integrated approach; Key elements; Rural tourisms; Tourist attractions; West javas; Rural areas

Authors: Kusumawardhana I., Tarigan W.P., Komsary K.C., Maulana Y.
Title: Dark tourism's products development: The cases of Fatahillah Dungeon and Taman Prasasti Museum
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kusumawardhana, I., Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Tarigan, W.P., Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Komsary, K.C., Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Maulana, Y., Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Despite academic interest in the tourism industry, there is a more sophisticated set of practice and thinking that could distinguish tourism products between mass and niche. Dark tourism, as the niche of tourism offers an economic value for tourists' consumption that forged between reality and imagination. However, few studies were found to understand the realm of development of dark tourism varieties and attractions, which associated with death and suffering from lower political and ideology to the highest range while consuming it. Therefore, alongside the analytical thinking towards the product's typology and variety, the examination of both SWOT (Strength, Weaknesses, Opportunity, Threats) model and TOWS (Threat-Opportunity & Weakness-Strength) matrix, synchronize the sites' elaboration resources and capabilities in which the dark tourism's place and space operate. Both of the qualitative case studies of Fatahillah Dungeon and Taman Prasasti museum provide the research practice that emerges from the visitors' voices. The findings deliver undiscovered value for the product development initiative, where at the same time bids the model for the dark tourism's consumption in term of the value creation and experience that giving the sites' meaning in recognizing how 'dark' the product is and stand out from the mass. © Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Museums; Tourism; Analytical thinking; Economic values; Qualitative case studies; Resources and capabilities; Value creation; Leisure industry
